title: Characterizing CD4 T cell differentiation in mouse small intestine using T cell transfer, lamina propria preparation, and flow cytometry
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of single cell suspension from spleen
Timing: 0.5 h
These steps describe how to prepare single cell suspension of splenocytes for target cells isolation by a specific commercial kit and fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS). Use a syringe plunger to mechanically digest the whole spleen from donor mice, then use ammonium-chloride-potassium (ACK) lysis buffer to remove red blood cells.
Add 10 mL ice-cold MACS buffer to one well of a 6-well plate for each spleen.
Collect the spleen from the donor mice once mice are euthanized by IACUC approved method and put the spleen in one well of a 6-well plate which is prepared in step 1.
Use a 100 μm strainer and the plunger from a 1 mL syringe to homogenize tissues on ice (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2909-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Spleen single-cell suspension protocol
(A) Spleen tissues are homogenized in 10 mL of MACS buffer on ice using a 100 μm strainer and the plunger from a 1 mL syringe.
(B) The resulting cell suspension is transferred and filtered through a 100 μm single-cell strainer into a new 50 mL tube.
(C) The cell suspension is then centrifuged at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C to pellet the cells after ammonium-chloride-potassium (ACK) lysis. The pellet, indicated by the red arrow, becomes white.
Put the 100 μm filter into a 50 mL tube and pass the homogenized tissues through the 100 μm strainer. Add another 5 mL MACS buffer to wash the strainer, then centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet. Lyse red blood cells with 3 mL of ACK lysis buffer for 10 min at 25°C with occasional shaking.
Stop lysis by adding 15 mL MACS buffer.

Critical: It is critical to pay attention to the lysis time and temperature in order to effectively eliminate red blood cells (RBCs) while ensuring the viability of white blood cells for subsequent steps. Careful control of these parameters is essential for successful experimental outcomes (troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1])
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Resuspend the cell pellet in 1 mL MACS buffer and count cells.
Note: Keep 5 × 106 cells in 500 μL MACS buffer single color compensation staining (step 20).
Magnetic labeling & magnetic separation
Timing: 0.5 h
These steps describe how to enrich CD4-positive cells from the spleen single cell suspension. The CD4 negative and positive cells are separated by the Miltenyi CD4+ T Cell isolation kit.
Critical: Keeping the whole procedure on the ice or at 4°C and working fast is essential for getting live CD4+ live cells. Long time or high temperature might decrease the cell viability and purity.
Note: The volume of reagent used below is sufficient for 107 or fewer cells. For more than 107 cells, scale up the volume according to the exact numbers.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet. Resuspend cell pellet 90 μL of buffer per 10⁷ total cells on ice.
Add 10 μL of CD4 L3T4 beads per 10⁷ total cells.
Mix well and incubate for 10 min in a refrigerator (2−8°C).
Place MS column in the magnetic field of a suitable MACS Separator.
Note: The MS column is sufficient for up to 107 labeled cells or 108 total cells. Choose the LS column for 107 to 108 labeled cells or 108 to 109 total cells.

Rinse MS column with 0.5 mL MACS buffer.
Note: For the LS column, use 3 mL MACS buffer.
Apply cell suspension onto the column.
Note: The minimal volume of the cell suspension is 0.5 mL. If necessary, add MACS buffer.
Wash the column with 0.5 mL MACS buffer twice.
Note: For the LS column, use 3 mL MACS buffer.
Remove the column from the separator and place it on a suitable collection tube. Pipette 1 mL MACS buffer onto the MS column. Immediately flush out the magnetically labeled CD4+ cells.
Note: For the LS column, use 5 mL MACS buffer.
Optional: Potential alternative CD4+ T cell isolation kits or CD4+ T cell negative selection isolation kits can be obtained from different companies, such as Biolegend and Stemcell technology, might serve as suitable replacements for the Miltenyi CD4+ T Cell Isolation Kit.
Antibody staining of naïve CD4+ cell for fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS)
Timing: 1 h
These steps describe how to stain and sort naïve CD4+ cells by flow cytometry.
Critical: Performing the procedure on ice or at 4°C and working quickly is vital for isolating live naïve CD4+ T cells. A prolonged procedure or high temperature might decrease the cell viability and purity.
Note: The volume of reagent and antibody used below is sufficient for 107 or fewer cells. For more than 107 cells, scale up the volume according to the exact numbers.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet (CD4+ T cells) 500 μL of Naïve CD4+ T cell staining cocktail containing CD4-PE, CD44- PE/Cyanine7, CD62L -APC antibody.
Optional: Other fluorescent dye-labeled forms can replace the antibodies used here.
Mix well and incubate for 30 min in a refrigerator (2−8°C).

Prepare single color compensation samples during the incubation.
Divide 5 × 106 spleen cells from step 8 to 5 wells of a 96-well plate. Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Add 100 μL FACS buffer containing 1 μg anti-mouse CD16/32 as an Fc blocking antibody, mix well, and incubate for 10 min at 25°C.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Add 100 μL appropriate antibody staining buffer (single color antibody), live/dead staining buffer (SYTOX™ Blue), or FACS buffer (unstained), mix well, and incubate for 10 min in a refrigerator (2−8°C).
Add 100 μL FACS buffer, mix well, and centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Add 100 μL FACS buffer, mix well, and transfer to 5 mL round bottom FACS tube with cell strainer snap cap and place on ice before going to cell sorting.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Wash the cells with 1 mL FACS buffer. Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Add 1 mL FACS buffer containing SYTOX™ Blue live/dead staining buffer, mix well, and transfer to a 5 mL round bottom FACS tube with cell strainer snap cap. Place on ice for at least 10 min before going to cell sorting.
Optional: The SYTOX™ Blue live/dead staining buffer can be substituted with alternative live-dead cell staining reagents, such as 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI).

Use single-color staining samples to set up appropriate compensation and unstained samples to set up baseline auto-fluorescence levels for different fluorochromes on the flow cytometry machine used for sorting.
Sort CD4+CD62L+ CD44- cells to 15 mL Falcon tubes containing 3 mL FACS buffer based on the gating strategy in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2909-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Gating strategy for sorting naïve CD4+ T cells
Representative plots depicting the gating strategy of CD4+CD62L+ CD44- naïve CD4+ T cells.
Note: Performing the sorting process at 4°C will help improve cellular viability.
Take a small fraction of the sorted sample for reexamination by flow cytometry to establish the purity.
Note: More than 95% of sorted cells are CD4+CD62L+CD44- live cells (troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3])
Intraperitoneal (IP) injection of the naïve CD4+ cells into recipient mice
Timing: 0.5 h
These steps describe using the intraperitoneal (IP) injection method to transfer naïve CD4+ T cells into recipient mice.
Critical: Injecting the cell to the correct location is critical; injection into the subcutaneous tissue will abrogate the transfer of cells.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet with cold PBS to 2.5 ×106 cells/mL.
Very slowly draw cells into a 1-mL syringe with a 27-G ½ inch needle attached.
Using a proper intraperitoneal (IP) injection technique, slowly inject 100 μL naïve CD4+ T cells into the recipient mouse (in this case, they are Rag2 −/− mice).
Secure the recipient mouse in a suitable position to access the peritoneal cavity.
Insert the 27-G ½ inch needle slowly and carefully into the peritoneal cavity.
Critical: Take caution to avoid damaging internal organs or causing unnecessary harm.
Slowly inject the 100 μL of naïve CD4+ T cell suspension into the peritoneal cavity.

Critical: Ensure a controlled and steady delivery to ensure even distribution
Gently withdraw the needle from the peritoneal cavity, avoiding any sudden movements.
Monitor the mice for signs of distress, adverse reactions, or complications.
House the recipient mice under specific pathogen-free (SPF) or other conditions required for the protocol and wait 5 weeks before analyzing CD4+ subsets in the small Intestine (SI) lamina propria (LP).
Isolation of lamina propria (LP) cells from the small intestine of recipient mice
Timing: 3–4 h
These steps describe how to isolate cells from the small intestinal lamina propria. In this portion of the protocol, the lamina propria of the ileum are disrupted by collagenase VIII and DNAase I treatment.
Preparing the necessary reagents in advance and allowing them to equilibrate to the desired temperature before handling the mice to collect the small Intestine is recommended. This will ensure that the reagents are at the correct temperature by the time you start the experiment and help maintain consistency and accuracy in your results.
Critical: Performing the isolation steps quickly and accurately is essential for obtaining live cells.
Note: This protocol can also be used to isolate cells from lamina propria of the colon or other mucosal tissues (troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5])
Add 10 mL ice-cold HBSS buffer containing 2% FCS to one well of a 6-well plate for each small intestine.
Collect 5–6 cm distal small Intestine (containing the ileum) from the recipient mice once mice are euthanized by an IACUCC approved method and put them in the one well of a 6-well plate which is prepared in step 32 (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2909-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Isolation of cells from small intestine lamina propria (LP)
(A) 5–6 cm small intestines are kept in 10 mL ice-cold HBSS buffer containing 2% FCS.

(B) Remove fat and peyer’s patches quickly on a wet tissue.
(C) Open the intestine longitudinally on wax.
(D) Cut the intestine into 1 cm segments using sterile scissors and transfer them into 20 mL of 1 × HBSS in a 50 mL Falcon tube.
(E) Remove supernatant with a strainer.
(F) Filter strained cell suspension through a fresh 100 μm cell filter into a new 50 mL tube.
Remove the fat and peyer’s patches on a wet tissue, and gently remove the luminal contents by stripping the serosal side of the intestines with a forceps (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Open the intestinal tissue placed on wax longitudinally (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Critical: Keeping the tissue moist during the experimental steps is crucial as dry tissues can lead to significant cell death. With practice, these steps can and should be performed as a continuous and rapid procedure to avoid tissue drying.
After opening the tissue longitudinally, place it back into the well of a 6-well plate with 10 mL ice-cold 1 × HBSS buffer containing 2% FCS and gently shake off intraluminal contents into the buffer.
Cut into 1 cm segments using sterile scissors and place them in 20 mL of 1 × HBSS in a 50 mL Falcon tube. Shake the tubes vigorously (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
Note: Add 20 mL 1 × HBSS ahead of time to the tubes.
Remove the supernatant with a strainer, recover the tissue segments, and add 20 mL 1 × HBSS containing 2 mM EDTA (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E).
Note: Add 5 mL 1 × HBSS containing 2 mM EDTA every 3–4 samples to avoid excessive tissue drying. Top off the volume to 20 mL before putting in the shaker.
Incubate at 37°C with shaking at 200–250 rpm for 30 min.

Remove the supernatant with a strainer, recover the tissue segments, and add 20 mL 1 × HBSS in the same tube.
Note: The tissues should become clear.
Shake tubes vigorously and remove the supernatant with a strainer. Recover tissue segments in a new 50 mL Falcon tube and add 15 mL 1 × HBSS containing 2 mM EDTA.
Note: Add 5 mL 1 × HBSS containing 2 mM EDTA every 3–4 samples to avoid excessive tissue drying. Top off the volume to 15 mL before putting in a shaker.
Incubate at 37°C with continuous shaking at 200–250 rpm for 20 min.
Prepare LPL digest medium by adding collagenase VIII and DNAase I to LPL buffer base pre-warmed in a 37°C water bath.
Remove the supernatant with a strainer, recover the tissue segments, and add 10 mL 1 × HBSS in the same tube.
Shake tubes vigorously and remove the supernatant with a strainer. Recover tissue segments to 10 mL prepared LPL digest medium (Step 43) in a new 50 mL Falcon tube.
Incubate at 37°C with continuous shaking at 200–250 rpm for 30 min.
Add 10 mL ice-cold FACS buffer.
Pass cell suspension through a 100 μm cell filter to a new 50 mL tube and wash cell strainer with 10 mL ice-cold FACS buffer (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]F).
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Resuspend the pellet in 5 mL FACS Buffer.
Pass the cell suspension through a 40 μm cell filter to a new 50 mL tube and wash the cell strainer with 10 mL ice-cold FACS buffer.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.

Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL ice-cold FACS medium and count the cells.
Note: If there are no cytokines to be detected by flow cytometry, you may skip the cytokine induction steps (54–57) and proceed directly to stain the samples.
Cytokine accumulation intracellularly for flow cytometric analysis
Timing: 4.5 h
These steps describe how to use phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA), ionomycin, and GolgiPlug (containing brefeldin A) to measure the cytokines inside the cells. PMA and ionomycin affect protein kinase C (PKC) and calcium ion influx and induce cytokine expression in the cells. GolgiPlug (containing brefeldin A) blocks intracellular transport processes and causes accumulation of most cytokine proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum/Golgi complex.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]
Critical: It is crucial to optimize the induction time for each cytokine. Induction times that are too long can result in significant cell death, while induction times that are too short may fail to induce enough cytokines. An induction time of 4–6 h is usually adequate for most cytokines (troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7])
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Resuspend the pellet in 0.9 mL culture medium and transfer to one well of a 24 well plate.
Add 100 μL culture medium, which contains PMA, ionomycin, and GolgiPlug (containing brefeldin A), to a final concentration of 50 ng/mL PMA, 500 ng/mL ionomycin and 1×GolgiPlug (containing brefeldin A).
Note: 1 mL culture medium containing PMA, ionomycin, and GolgiPlug (containing brefeldin A) is sufficient to induce cytokine expression in 1–5 million cells.
Incubate at 37°C for 4–6 h before antibody staining.
Antibody staining of CD4 subset
Timing: 3 h
These steps describe how to stain the LP cells with surface and intercellular antibodies which are used to define the CD4 subsets.

Critical: keeping the whole procedure on ice or at 4°C and working quickly is vital for obtaining proper results.
Note: The volume of reagent and antibody used below is sufficient for 5 × 106 or fewer cells. According to our experience, 5–6 cm of the distal small intestine (containing the ileum) produces 1–5 × 106 cells.
After cytokine induction, transfer the 1 mL cell suspension to one well of a 96-well round bottom plate.
Note: all subsequent steps should be performed in the 96-well plate. If you only have a few samples, 5 mL FACS tubes can be used instead.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 200 μL FACS buffer containing 1 μg anti-mouse CD16/32 as an Fc blocking antibody.
Mix well and incubate for 10 min in the refrigerator (2−8°C).
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet in 200 μL FACS buffer containing surface marker antibodies and LIVE/DEAD® Fixable Aqua Dead Cell Staining solution.
Optional: The LIVE/DEAD® Fixable Aqua Dead Cell Staining solution can be potentially replaced with an alternative live-dead cell staining reagent that is compatible with fixation and permeabilization processes required for intracellular antibody staining.
Mix well and incubate for 30 min in the refrigerator (2−8°C).
Use commercially available antibody-capture beads to prepare single-color compensation samples during the incubation as described in step 20.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Wash the cells with 200 μL FACS buffer. Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.

Add 200 μL fresh mixed FOXP3 transcription factor staining buffer to each well.
Mix the well and incubate for 30 min in the refrigerator (2−8°C).
Pause point: The samples can be left in the FOXP3 transcription factor staining buffer in the refrigerator (2−8°C) for 16–20h.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Wash the cells with 200 μL FACS buffer. Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Resuspend cell pellet in 200 μL permeabilization buffer from the FOXP3 transcription factor kit containing intracellular staining antibodies.
Mix well and incubate for 30 min in the refrigerator (2−8°C).
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Wash the cells with a 200 μL permeabilization buffer. Centrifuge at 500 × g for 10 min at 4°C. Pour off the supernatant to retain the cell pellet.
Add 200 μL FACS buffer, mix well, place on ice, and are ready for flow cytometry machine.
Pause point: The samples can be left in FACS buffer in the refrigerator (2−8°C) for 1 or 2 days. Samples should be kept at 4°C in the dark during this period.
Data acquired by flow cytometry and analysis
Timing: 1–3 h
These steps use the CytoFLEX LX flow cytometer (Beckman Coulter) to acquire the data for further analysis by FlowJo software v10 (TreeStar).
Alternatives: Depending on the accessibility, these steps can use other flow cytometer machines to acquire data according to manufactory protocols.
Before acquiring data, use the CytoFLEX daily QC fluorosphere beads to run a QC/standardization program to ensure the flow cytometer works properly.

Use single-color staining samples to set up an appropriate level of compensation and unstained samples to define the baseline level of auto-fluorescence for different fluorochromes on the flow cytometry machine used.
Collect the data on the CytoFLEX LX flow cytometer (Beckman Coulter).
When analyzing the data using FlowJo, gate the samples according to the gating strategy shown in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2909-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Gating strategy for Th17, Treg, Th1, and Th2 cells
Representative plots depicting gating strategy of CD45+TCRβ+CD4+IL17A + Th17 cells, CD45+TCRβ+CD4+ GATA3+ Th2 cells, CD45+TCRβ+CD4+IFN-γ+ Th1 cells , and CD45+TCRβ+CD4+ FOXP3+ Treg cells. Adapted from Duan et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
